My manager is biased.
My client is difficult.
My work is boring.
My salary is low.

We repeat these lines like a broken record.

But deep down, we know the truth:

- Build something of our own.

Yet, instead of acting, we choose to complain.
And thatâ€™s the biggest lie we tell others and ourselves.

I know the word that scares you the most:
ğ—£ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—•ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´!

Putting yourself out there in front of the world can feel terrifying.
Every post feels like youâ€™re standing under a spotlight you never asked for.

But hereâ€™s the thing:
For your career and your growth, you canâ€™t hide forever.

The good news?

You donâ€™t have to share your deepest secrets.

You just have to talk about your work:
- Work in progress â†’ share your process.
- Lessons learned â†’ insights from projects or challenges.
- Tools & resources â†’ what helps you do your job better.

content:
ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—§ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜† ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ—£ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—» ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—»â€™ğ˜?

Itâ€™s about how life is respected!

I saw stray dogs sleeping peacefully on sidewalks.
Cats resting in shop corners, cafes, and on benches.
People walking beside them, without fear and disgust.

So much peace in presence.

No harassment.
No discrimination.
Women. Children. Animals. Everyone moves freely. Exists safely.

And it shows.
In how well-fed and groomed the animals are.
In how calm the environment feels, like the city breathes peace.

And it made me wonder:

Why not us? Why not Pakistan?
If Istanbul can do it, So can we.

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
Things my teachers cared about:
- Why didnâ€™t you cut your hair?
- What color is that tie?
- Why are your sleeves folded up?
- Why are your shoes white and not black?
- Why are you not standing straight in the assembly?

They cared about everything except what really mattered!

I wish just one teacher had:
- Helped me choose a path based on my personality.
- Encouraged me to pursue an unconventional career.
- Supported me instead of trying to discipline me.

But NO.
They forced me to fit in. And I was never meant to.
It became a battle that I fought silently, every day.

If youâ€™re a teacher reading this, please:
Be more than a rule-enforcer.
Be a mentor. Be someone your students trust.
Because youâ€™re holding the future in your classroom.
style_notes: Reflective, narrative, motivational, critical of traditional schooling

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
LinkedIn > Instagram
There, I said it.

Why, you ask?
Thatâ€™s the same question Iâ€™ve been asking myself for the past one year. I finally have the answer.

I have over half a million people who follow me on Instagram. I make all my money on Instagram. But thereâ€™s one thing Instagram doesnâ€™t have:

That is our LinkedIn community.

That is people who want to learn something, who want to progress in life, who want to share their success stories, who want to inspire others, who comment "CFBR" to help strangers they have never met.

I havenâ€™t met 99% of you, and yet I deeply feel so connected with all of you.

At the end, itâ€™s all of us together who make this the best platform on social media.

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
I watched a suspense movie without skippingâ€¦which is rare.

I usually tap ahead every few minutes.

Cause I am impatient, try to guess the ending, and skip all the build-up part.

But this time I didnâ€™t.
I needed to figure out who the stalker was before they revealed it.

So I could be like, â€œyep. called it.â€

And I realizedâ€¦thatâ€™s exactly how your content should feel.
It should give people enough context to feel like theyâ€™re inside the story...

like they know the stakes, the tension, the â€œwhy now.â€

So how do you actually create that?

1. Set the scene
â€œClient project failedâ€ â†’ forgettable
â€œ3 days from launch & the devs ghosted.â€ â†’ now I care.

2. Show where this moment fits
Was this your first client? A turning point? Let people know why it mattered.

3. Add small stakes
What did you risk? What was on the line? Even tiny tension makes people stay.

Context-led content works because it lets your reader feel the moment before they try to learn from it.

It turns a post into a scene. And scenes are what we stay for.
style_notes: Instructional, narrative, practical guidance, suspense metaphor

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
We complain a lot about Pakistan.
The power cuts. The internet drops. The poor education.
The endless little roadblocks that make work feel 10x harder than it should be.

But hereâ€™s the thing nobody talks about...
â†’ Our campaigns are on billboards in London.
â†’ Our words are selling products in Dubai.
â†’ Our code is running in Silicon Valley.

Half the time, people donâ€™t even know itâ€™s us.
â†’ Weâ€™ve built startups from bedrooms.
â†’ Turned 3G into 7-figure freelance careers.
â†’ Made brands look world-class without charging NY rates.

Weâ€™re not â€œwaiting to be discovered.â€ Weâ€™re already building, shipping, and delivering for the world.
Every roadblock is fuel. Every setback is a dare.

Thatâ€™s the real Pakistan. Messy. Chaotic. Relentless. And absolutely unstoppable.

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
Only a tiny % of your audience is ready to buy right now.

Everyone else?
- Theyâ€™re in research mode.
- Theyâ€™re watching. Not acting.
- Theyâ€™re problem-aware but not product-ready.

Most content accidentally ghosts your warmest leads.
You donâ€™t need more content. You need smarter content, built for 3 types of people:

1. â€œI think I have a problem, but Iâ€™m not sure yet.â€
Give them checklists, posts naming the problem, client stories.

2. â€œI know I need help, but I don't know the best option.â€
Give them comparisons, real results, why X didnâ€™t work and what you did.

3. â€œIâ€™m ready, but I need to trust you first.â€
Give them FAQs, process, micro testimonials.

Want help mapping your content to real buyer stages? Thatâ€™s literally what I do. DMs open (Only 1 slot available)

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
I went missing. (Yes, again. For the 67th time.)

But this timeâ€¦it was for all the good reasons:
+ I onboarded 2 dream clients. (super-busy)
+ I revamped my website (and 4 sub-domains).
+ I built my design & dev team for MVP project.
+ I wanted to be more clear on my strategy & work.
+ I didn't want to LinkedIn just for the sake of doing it.

And somewhere in this breakâ€¦I found my groove.

Before this glow-up break, I was running on autopilot.
- Work was â€œworking.â€
- Clients were happy and satisfied.
- Growth looked good from the outside.

But everything still felt off.
I was showing up but not really there. Burnt out, bored, and barely connected to the things Iâ€™d built.

So I hit pause. And:
â†’ Focus on chasing fulfilment instead of grind
â†’ Revisit the 2025 goals I crushed despite doubt
â†’ Rebuilt my space, my energy, and how I show up

Till the 31st December 2025, here's what I plan to do:
+ Creative space for things Iâ€™ve been waiting for â€œsomedayâ€
+ Work that fits into my life, not the other way around
+ Post on my socials and blog with clearer intention
+ Keeping my peace at the top of the priority list

Because lifeâ€™s too precious to be wasted in a loop you donâ€™t love.

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
I used to overthink everything I wanted to do.
- Should I do this?
- What if it sounds dumb?
- What if someone smarter calls me out?

But hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned:
Most things that change the world look stupid at first.
1. Colonel Sanders â†’ Rejected 1,000+ times at age 65.
2. JK Rowling â†’ 12 publishers rejected Harry Potter.
3. Walt Disney â†’ Fired for â€œlacking imagination.â€

Imagine if theyâ€™d listened. Imagine if theyâ€™d stayed quiet to â€œlook smart.â€
The fear of looking stupid is sneaky. It keeps you in the background. It convinces you to wait. To play it safe. To blend in.

But safe doesnâ€™t build anything.

So hereâ€™s what Iâ€™m telling myself lately:
+ Say the idea.
+ Share the post.
+ Ask the question.
Even if it feels awkward. Even if your voice shakes.

Looking stupid is temporary. But staying stuck? That can last years.

Ps: What's the one thing you always wanted to try but fear that people might call it stupid or a dumb idea?
